Award.AwardTitle: Development and Application of Synthetic Receptors for Methylated Lysine and Arginine for Methyltransferase Assays
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Marcey Waters from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. While every cell in an individual person has the same genes, not all genes in a cell are expressed. Gene expression is the process by which genetic instructions are used to synthesize genetic products. Differences in gene expression lead to differentiation, such that a skin cell is different from a liver cell, for example. Research into understanding how genes are expressed is an important area because the factors that control gene expression can lead to many diseases. One factor that controls gene expression, but that is poorly understood, is a phenomenon called protein methylation, which involves the "tagging" of certain proteins with a molecule, here a methyl group. Studies indicate that incorrect methylation is a critical component in many diseases, particularly cancer, and that the processes that lead to methylation are potential medicinal targets. However, the ability to detect methylation is currently severely limited. Dr. Waters is developing new detection tools for rapidly sensing methylation, and determining when incorrect methylation occurs. This project is also supporting continued efforts to increase diversity in science fields and provide undergraduate and graduate student research opportunities for those from underrepresented groups.

This research project is developing synthetic receptors as molecular sensors for methylated lysine and arginine, which are being used to characterize the enzymes that install and remove these post-translational modifications. Dysregulation of lysine and arginine methylation has been linked to a wide range of diseases, yet the tools available for sensing these modifications are limited and this has hindered advancements in the field. These approaches include the use of antibodies, which are expensive and have been shown to give false negatives; radioactive labeling, which is a low-throughput single-timepoint assay and requires specialized equipment and safety protocols; and mass spectrometry, which is time consuming and requires very sensitive, expensive equipment. The approach taken in this proposal is providing a rapid, real-time, high throughput, fluorogenic sensing method, which is enabling a significant advancement in the ability to characterize lysine and arginine methylation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research Summary.  Lysine (Lys) and Arginine (Arg) methylation of histone proteins is intimately involved in the epigenetic regulation of gene expression. These post-translational modifications (PTMs) function by recruiting non-histone proteins to chromatin, dictating the higher-order chromatin structure in which DNA is packaged, and resulting in gene expression or gene silencing depending on the type and location of the PTM. Dysregulation of Lys and Arg methylation has been associated with a wide range of diseases.  Thus, there is great interest in detecting the level and degree of methylation in histone proteins.  However, the currently available methods have significant limitations, including up to 25% failure rate for detection by antibodies. The goal of this research was to develop a set of novel selective receptors for all of the methylation states of lysine and arginine that can be applied to sensing these PTMs. 

To this end, we used a library-based platform for developing receptors for these PTMs and have successfully developed selective receptors for trimethyllysine, dimethyllysine, and asymmetric dimethylarginine that bind as or more tightly than the native proteins that they aimed to mimic.  The success of this work advances our fundamental understanding of how to selectively bind and differentiate similar hydrophilic guests in aqueous solution and provides the necessary molecular receptors to develop sensors for methylated Lys and Arg.

Using these receptors, we have also developed three different platforms for utilizing these receptors as sensors. The first uses pattern recognition and successfully distinguishes all eight methylation states of Lys and Arg. The second expands on the first to introduce a fluorescence readout. The third converts a reversible binding event into a stable covalent tagging in a catalytic manner to provide both a readout and method for separating methylated histone tails.

Intellectual Merit.  This work has provided new fundamental insights into strategies to selectively recognize the different methylation states of Lys and Arg. More broadly this work has advanced the fundamental understanding of strategies to selectively recognize hydrophilic guests. Furthermore, this work has developed three novel supramolecular sensing strategies for detecting methylated Lys and Arg that will advance our ability to characterize methylation states in biological systems.

Broader Impacts.  This work has provided interdisciplinary research opportunities for a number of graduate students and undergraduates, including underrepresented groups in STEM, including UNC students during the semester and NSF REU students in the summer.  The research exposed students to methods in organic, analytical, supramolecular chemistry, and biochemistry, providing a strong interdisciplinary background, which is necessary in an increasingly interdisciplinary workforce. Beyond the lab, the graduate students on the project and I participated in community outreach and STEM communication through a number of programs, including the UNC Science Expo, which attracts over 10,000 participants each year, Science in the Stacks at the town library, and an outreach program at a local middle school.
